column1: //A contract address to a new upgraded contract if any
/* Burn PARENT_CANNOT_CONTROL and CANNOT_UNWRAP fuses for ROOT_NODE and ETH_NODE */
* @notice Set the metadata service. Only the owner can do this
* @return String uri of the metadata service
function uri(uint256 tokenId) public view override returns (string memory) {
* @notice Set the address of the upgradeContract of the contract. only admin can do this
* @dev The default value of upgradeContract is the 0 address. Use the 0 address at any time
* to make the contract not upgradable.
* @notice Checks if msg.sender is the owner or approved by the owner of a name
* @param node namehash of the name to check
* @notice Checks if owner or approved by owner
* @param node namehash of the name to check
* @param addr which address to check permissions for
* @return whether or not is owner or approved
* @notice Gets fuse permissions for a specific name
* @dev Fuses are represented by a uint32 where each permission is represented by 1 bit
*      The interface has predefined fuses for all registry permissions, but additional
*      fuses can be added for other use cases
*      Also returns expiry, which is when the fuses are set to expire.
* @param node namehash of the name to check
* @return fuses A number that represents the permissions a name has. Returns 0 when expiry < block.timestamp
* @return expiry Unix time of when the name expires and fuses are to expire
* @notice Wraps a .eth domain, creating a new token and sending the original ERC721 token to this contract
* @dev Can be called by the owner of the name on the .eth registrar or an authorised caller on the registrar
* @param label label as a string of the .eth domain to wrap
* @param wrappedOwner Owner of the name in this contract
* @param expiry when the fuses will expire
// transfer the token from the user to this contract
// transfer the ens record back to the new owner (this contract)
* @dev Registers a new .eth second-level domain and wraps it.
* @param label The label to register (Eg, 'foo' for 'foo.eth').
* @param wrappedOwner The owner of the wrapped name.
* @param duration The duration, in seconds, to register the name for.
* @param resolver The resolver address to set on the ENS registry (optional).
* @param expiry when the fuses will expire
* @return registrarExpiry The expiry date of the new name on the .eth registrar, in seconds since the Unix epoch.
* @param tokenId The hash of the label to register (eg, `keccak256('foo')`, for 'foo.eth').
* @param duration The number of seconds to renew the name for.
* @return expires The expiry date of the name on the .eth registrar, in seconds since the Unix epoch.
(address owner, uint32 fuses, uint64 oldExpiry) = getData(
* @notice Wraps a non .eth domain, of any kind. Could be a DNSSEC name vitalik.xyz or a subdomain
* @dev Can be called by the owner in the registry or an authorised caller in the registry
* @param name The name to wrap, in DNS format
* @param wrappedOwner Owner of the name in this contract
* @dev Can be called by the owner in the wrapper or an authorised caller in the wrapper
* @param newRegistrant sets the owner in the .eth registrar to this address
* @param newController sets the owner in the registry to this address
* @notice Unwraps a non .eth domain, of any kind. Could be a DNSSEC name vitalik.xyz or a subdomain
* @dev Can be called by the owner in the wrapper or an authorised caller in the wrapper
* @param parentNode parent namehash of the name e.g. vitalik.xyz would be namehash('xyz')
* @param labelhash labelhash of the name, e.g. vitalik.xyz would be keccak256('vitalik')
* @param newController sets the owner in the registry to this address
* @param fuses fuses to burn (cannot burn PARENT_CANOT_CONTROL)
// Only the parent can burn the PARENT_CANNOT_CONTROL fuse.
(address owner, uint32 oldFuses, uint64 expiry) = getData(
* @notice Upgrades a .eth wrapped domain by calling the wrapETH2LD function of the upgradeContract
*     and burning the token of this contract
* @dev Can be called by the owner of the name in this contract
* @param label Label as a string of the .eth name to upgrade
* @param wrappedOwner The owner of the wrapped name
* @notice Upgrades a non .eth domain of any kind. Could be a DNSSEC name vitalik.xyz or a subdomain
* @dev Can be called by the owner or an authorised caller
* Requires upgraded Namewrapper to permit old Namewrapper to call `setSubnodeRecord` for all names
* @param parentNode namehash of the parent name
* @param label Label as a string of the name to upgrade
* @param wrappedOwner Owner of the name in this contract
* @param resolver resolver contract for this name
/* @notice Sets fuses of a name that you own the parent of. Can also be called by the owner of a .eth name
* @param parentNode parent namehash of the name e.g. vitalik.xyz would be namehash('xyz')
* @param labelhash labelhash of the name, e.g. vitalik.xyz would be keccak256('vitalik')
* @param expiry when the fuses will expire
(address owner, uint32 oldFuses, uint64 oldExpiry) = getData(
// max expiry is set to the expiry on the registrar
// max expiry is set to the expiry of the parent
// if PARENT_CANNOT_CONTROL has been burned and fuses have changed
* @notice Sets the subdomain owner in the registry and then wraps the subdomain
* @param parentNode parent namehash of the subdomain
* @param label label of the subdomain as a string
* @param fuses initial fuses for the wrapped subdomain
* @param expiry when the fuses will expire
* @notice Sets the subdomain owner in the registry with records and then wraps the subdomain
* @param parentNode parent namehash of the subdomain
* @param label label of the subdomain as a string
* @param resolver resolver contract in the registry
* @param fuses initial fuses for the wrapped subdomain
* @param expiry expiry date for the domain
* @notice Sets records for the name in the ENS Registry
* @param node namehash of the name to set a record for
* @notice Sets resolver contract in the registry
* @dev Allows an operation only if none of the specified fuses are burned.
* @param node The namehash of the name to check fuses on.
* @param fuseMask A bitmask of fuses that must not be burned.
* @notice Check whether a name can call setSubnodeOwner/setSubnodeRecord
* @dev Checks both canCreateSubdomain and canReplaceSubdomain and whether not they have been burnt
*      and checks whether the owner of the subdomain is 0x0 for creating or already exists for
*      replacing a subdomain. If either conditions are true, then it is possible to call
* @param node namehash of the name to check
* @param labelhash labelhash of the name to check
* @notice Checks all Fuses in the mask are burned for the node
* @param fuseMask the fuses you want to check
* @return Boolean of whether or not all the selected fuses are burned
//check if it's the eth registrar ERC721
// transfer the ens record back to the new owner (this contract)
function _canTransfer(uint32 fuses) internal pure override returns (bool) {
function _addLabel(string memory label, bytes memory name)
// burn and unwrap old token of old owner
emit NameWrapped(node, name, wrappedOwner, fuses, expiry)
// Expiry cannot be more than maximum allowed
// .eth names will check registrar, non .eth check parent
// Expiry cannot be less than old expiry
// Mint a new ERC1155 token with fuses
// Set PARENT_CANNOT_REPLACE to reflect wrapper + registrar control over the 2LD
function _canFusesBeBurned(bytes32 node, uint32 fuses) internal pure {
}",7024.0,963.0,"[H-01] It is possible to create fake ERC1155 NameWrapper token for subdomain, which is not owned by NameWrapper

Due to re-entrancy possibility in `NameWrapper._transferAndBurnFuses` (called from `setSubnodeOwner` and `setSubnodeRecord`), it is possible to do some stuff in onERC1155Received right after transfer but before new owner and new fuses are set. This makes it possible, for example, to unwrap the subdomain, but owner and fuses will still be set even for unwrapped domain, creating fake ERC1155 NameWrapper token for domain, which is not owned by NameWrapper.
[H-02] The expiry of the parent node can be smaller than the one of a child node, violating the guarantee policy

By design, the child node's expiry can only be extended up to the parent's current one. Adding these restrictions means that the ENS users only have to look at the name itself's fuses and expiry (without traversing the hierarchy) to understand what guarantees the users have.

When a parent node tries to `setSubnodeOwner / setSubnodeRecord`, the following code is used to guarantee that the new expiry can only be extended up to the current one.   [H-03] `PARENT_CANNOT_CONTROL` can be bypassed by maliciously unwrapping parent node
By design, for any subdomain, as long as its `PARENT_CANNOT_CONTROL` fuse is burnt (and does not expire), its parent should not be able to burn its fuses or change its owner.

However, this contraint can be bypassed by a parent node maliciously unwrapping itself. As long as the hacker becomes the ENS owner of the parent node, he can leverage ENSRegistry::setSubnodeOwner to re-set himself as the ENS owner of the subdomain, and thus re-invoking the function `wrap` can rewrite the fuses and wrapper owner of the given subdoamin.   [M-01] wrapETH2LD permissioning is over-extended

Current permissioning for the function `wrapETH2LD` allows `msg.senders` who are not owner to call it if they are EITHER approved for all on the ERC721 registrar or approved on the wrapper. Allowing users who are approved for the ERC721 registrar makes sense. By giving them approval, you are giving them approval to do what they wish with the token.   [M-07] If `PARENT_CANNOT_CONTROL` is set on subdomain, it can be unwrapped then wrapped by its owner and then parent can control it again before the expiry

There is a general incorrect logic of allowing to burn only `PARENT_CANNOT_CONTROL` fuse without burning `CANNOT_UNWRAP` fuse. If only `PARENT_CANNOT_CONTROL` fuse is burnt, then domain can be unwrapped by its owner and then wrapped again, which clears `PARENT_CANNOT_CONTROL` fuse, making it possible for parent to bypass the limitation of parent control before the expiry.",5.0,"pragma solidity ^0.8.4

function _canTransfer(uint32 fuses) internal pure override returns (bool) {
function _addLabel(string memory label, bytes memory name)
emit NameWrapped(node, name, wrappedOwner, fuses, expiry)
function _canFusesBeBurned(bytes32 node, uint32 fuses) internal pure {
}",4828.0,3,2,"Here is a list of vulnerabilities and potential issues in the provided smart contract:
- **`wrapETH2LD`**: The `label` parameter is not validated for length or format, which could lead to invalid or malicious inputs.
- **`registerAndWrapETH2LD`**: The `label` parameter is not validated, which could lead to invalid or malicious inputs.
- **`upgradeETH2LD`**: The `label` parameter is not validated, which could lead to invalid or malicious inputs.
- **`upgrade`**: The `label` parameter is not validated, which could lead to invalid or malicious inputs.
- **`setSubnodeOwner`**: The `label` parameter is not validated, which could lead to invalid or malicious inputs.
- **`setSubnodeRecord`**: The `label` parameter is not validated, which could lead to invalid or malicious inputs.
- **`wrapETH2LD`**: The contract transfers ownership of the token from the registrant to itself and then calls `_wrapETH2LD`. If `_wrapETH2LD` calls an external contract, it could lead to reentrancy.

- **`unwrapETH2LD`**: The contract transfers ownership of the token from itself to the new registrant after burning the token. If the new registrant is a malicious contract, it could reenter the function.
- **`unwrap`**: The contract transfers ownership of the token from itself to the new owner after burning the token. If the new owner is a malicious contract, it could reenter the function.
- **`setMetadataService`**: Only the owner can call this function, but there is no mechanism to ensure the new metadata service is trustworthy.
- **`setUpgradeContract`**: Only the owner can call this function, but there is no mechanism to ensure the new upgrade contract is trustworthy.
- **`wrapETH2LD`**: The function checks if the caller is the registrant or approved, but it does not validate the `wrappedOwner` address.
- **`registerAndWrapETH2LD`**: Only the controller can call this function, but there is no mechanism to ensure the controller is trustworthy.
- **`renew`**: Only the controller can call this function, but there is no mechanism to ensure the controller is trustworthy.
- **`onERC721Received`**: The function does not handle the case where `abi.decode` fails, which could lead to unexpected behavior.
- **`_prepareUpgrade`**: The function does not handle the case where `getFuses` fails, which could lead to unexpected behavior.
- **`_normaliseExpiry`**: The function compares `expiry`, `oldExpiry`, and `maxExpiry` without checking for potential integer overflow or underflow.
- **`setChildFuses`**: The function compares `expiry`, `oldExpiry`, and `maxExpiry` without checking for potential integer overflow or underflow.
- **`wrap`**: The function reads the entire `name` parameter, which could be arbitrarily long and lead to out-of-gas errors.
- **`_addLabelAndWrap`**: The function concatenates strings, which could lead to out-of-gas errors for long labels or names.
- **`setMetadataService`**: The function does not emit an event when the metadata service is updated.
- **`setUpgradeContract`**: The function does not emit an event when the upgrade contract is updated.
- **`setFuses`**: The function emits an event, but it does not include the old fuses for comparison.
- **`wrapETH2LD`**: An attacker could front-run the transaction to transfer the token to themselves before the contract can claim it.
- **`unwrapETH2LD`**: An attacker could front-run the transaction to transfer the token to themselves before the contract can transfer it to the new registrant.
- **`onERC721Received`**: The function assumes that the token being received is from the `registrar` contract, but it does not validate the token type or ensure that the token is valid.
- **`setUpgradeContract`**: If the upgrade contract is set to a malicious address, there is no way to recover from this.
- **`setMetadataService`**: If the metadata service is set to a malicious address, there is no way to recover from this.
- **`upgradeETH2LD`**: The function does not have a modifier to restrict access, allowing anyone to call it.
- **`upgrade`**: The function does not have a modifier to restrict access, allowing anyone to call it.
- **`_wrapETH2LD`**: The function sets `PARENT_CANNOT_CONTROL` fuse without checking if it is already set, which could lead to inconsistent state.
- **`_unwrap`**: The function does not check if the node is already unwrapped, which could lead to inconsistent state.
- **`_addLabel`**: The function reverts if the label is too short or too long, which could be exploited to cause a denial of service.
- **`_normaliseExpiry`**: The function reverts if the expiry is invalid, which could be exploited to cause a denial of service.
- The contract lacks sufficient comments and documentation, making it difficult to understand the intended behavior and potential risks.
- **`setUpgradeContract`**: The function makes external calls to `registrar.setApprovalForAll` and `ens.setApprovalForAll` without checking the return values, which could lead to unexpected behavior.
- **`upgradeETH2LD`**: The function makes an external call to `upgradeContract.wrapETH2LD` without checking the return value, which could lead to unexpected behavior.
- **`upgrade`**: The function makes an external call to `upgradeContract.setSubnodeRecord` without checking the return value, which could lead to unexpected behavior.
- **`wrapETH2LD`**: The function transfers the token from the registrant to the contract and then reclaims it. If the token is transferred to another address in between, the function could fail.
- **`unwrapETH2LD`**: The function burns the token and then transfers it to the new registrant. If the token is transferred to another address in between, the function could fail.
- **`_addLabelAndWrap`**: The function concatenates strings and then wraps the node, which could lead to inefficient gas usage for long labels or names.
- **`_getDataAndNormaliseExpiry`**: The function makes multiple calls to `getData`, which could lead to inefficient gas usage.
- **`_canFusesBeBurned`**: The function checks if the fuses can be burned, but the logic may not cover all edge cases.
- **`_normaliseExpiry`**: The function normalizes the expiry, but the logic may not cover all edge cases.
- The contract does not implement a proper upgradeability mechanism, making it difficult to fix bugs or add new features in the future.
- The `onlyOwner` modifier is used in several functions, but there is no mechanism to ensure that the owner is trustworthy or to recover from a compromised owner.

This list highlights the vulnerabilities and potential issues in the provided smart contract. Addressing these issues would improve the security, reliability, and maintainability of the contract.","### **Comparison of Issue Report and Response List**
#### **[H-01] It is possible to create fake ERC1155 NameWrapper token for subdomain, which is not owned by NameWrapper**

Due to re-entrancy possibility in `NameWrapper._transferAndBurnFuses` (called from `setSubnodeOwner` and `setSubnodeRecord`), it is possible to execute actions in `onERC1155Received` right after transfer but before new owner and fuses are set. This allows unwrapping the subdomain, but the owner and fuses remain set for the unwrapped domain, creating a fake ERC1155 NameWrapper token for a domain not owned by NameWrapper.
Matches with the issue titled **""Reentrancy Vulnerabilities""** under `wrapETH2LD`, `unwrapETH2LD`, and `unwrap`.

**Correct**. The response accurately identifies reentrancy vulnerabilities in functions like `wrapETH2LD` and `unwrapETH2LD`, which aligns with the issue described in the report. The potential for reentrancy in `_transferAndBurnFuses` is correctly captured, even though the specific function name is not mentioned.
#### **[H-02] The expiry of the parent node can be smaller than the one of a child node, violating the guarantee policy**

By design, the child node's expiry can only be extended up to the parent's current one. However, when a parent node tries to `setSubnodeOwner` or `setSubnodeRecord`, the code does not enforce this guarantee, allowing the child node's expiry to exceed the parent's expiry. This violates the policy that users should only need to look at the name itself's fuses and expiry to understand guarantees.

**Incorrect**. The response list does not address the issue of expiry hierarchy enforcement in `setSubnodeOwner` or `setSubnodeRecord`. This is a critical oversight, as it directly impacts the contract's design guarantees.
#### **[H-03] `PARENT_CANNOT_CONTROL` can be bypassed by maliciously unwrapping parent node**

By design, if the `PARENT_CANNOT_CONTROL` fuse is burnt for a subdomain, the parent should not be able to burn its fuses or change its owner. However, this constraint can be bypassed if the parent node maliciously unwraps itself. A hacker who becomes the ENS owner of the parent node can use `ENSRegistry::setSubnodeOwner` to re-set themselves as the ENS owner of the subdomain, allowing them to re-invoke `wrap` and rewrite the fuses and wrapper owner of the subdomain.
**Incorrect**. The response list does not address the bypass of `PARENT_CANNOT_CONTROL` through malicious unwrapping. This is a significant security issue that is entirely missed.

The current permissioning for `wrapETH2LD` allows `msg.senders` who are not the owner to call it if they are either approved for all on the ERC721 registrar or approved on the wrapper. While allowing users approved for the ERC721 registrar makes sense, extending this permission to those approved on the wrapper is over-permissive and could lead to unintended behavior.
Matches with the issue titled **""Improper Access Control""** under `wrapETH2LD`.
**Correct**. The response accurately identifies improper access control in `wrapETH2LD`, specifically the over-extended permissioning. This aligns with the issue described in the report.
#### **[M-07] If `PARENT_CANNOT_CONTROL` is set on subdomain, it can be unwrapped then wrapped by its owner and then parent can control it again before the expiry**

There is a general incorrect logic of allowing the `PARENT_CANNOT_CONTROL` fuse to be burnt without burning the `CANNOT_UNWRAP` fuse. If only `PARENT_CANNOT_CONTROL` is burnt, the domain can be unwrapped by its owner and then wrapped again, which clears the `PARENT_CANNOT_CONTROL` fuse. This allows the parent to bypass the limitation of parent control before the expiry.
**Incorrect**. The response list does not address the issue of `PARENT_CANNOT_CONTROL` being bypassed through unwrapping and rewrapping. This is a critical logic flaw that is entirely missed.
- **[H-01] It is possible to create fake ERC1155 NameWrapper token for subdomain, which is not owned by NameWrapper**
- **[H-02] The expiry of the parent node can be smaller than the one of a child node, violating the guarantee policy**
- **[H-03] `PARENT_CANNOT_CONTROL` can be bypassed by maliciously unwrapping parent node**
- **[M-07] If `PARENT_CANNOT_CONTROL` is set on subdomain, it can be unwrapped then wrapped by its owner and then parent can control it again before the expiry**

The response list covers some issues, such as reentrancy and improper access control, but misses critical vulnerabilities related to expiry hierarchy enforcement, `PARENT_CANNOT_CONTROL` bypass, and logic flaws in fuse handling. These gaps highlight the need for a more comprehensive review of the contract's design and implementation.",2,0,3,20,"```

}",2905.0,320.0,"[M-04] BytesUtil.compare returns wrong result on some strings longer than 32 characters

Due to incorrect condition in `ByteUtil.compare` function, irrelevant characters are masked out only for strings shorter than 32 characters. However, they must be masked out for strings of all lengths in the last pass of the loop (when remainder of the string is 32 characters or less). This leads to incorrect comparision of strings longer than 32 characters where len or otherlen is smaller than string length (characters beyond provided length are still accounted for in the comparision in this case while they should be ignored).
[M-06] BytesUtils: compare will not revert when the `offset` and `len` exceeds the bytes lengths
Compare will return false answer without reverting when the inputs are not valid.
The function `equals` with offset might return true when equals without offset returns false.",3.0,"pragma solidity ^0.8.4
